text: I'm working as a Client Service Worker at a City-operated shelter. Work environment is challenging but it is a rewarding job if you have empathy and tolerance. Pay is good, but you should be available for shift work including overtime shift.
pros: Good pay + benefit programs, contribution toward community, relationship building opportunity with co-workers during the shift
cons: Challenging work environment including the facility and people

text: No career growth potential. Management is heavily incompetent. In a labor position the levels of politics is staggering. The union protects the most useless of people and the few competent people end up picking up the slack or just being defeated. You very often get paid to do nothing which if thats your thing then this is the place to be. If you have any ambition or like problem solving or even just keeping g busy this place will drive you insane. Then the work you do is almost always pointless and somehow wrapped in red tape and just utter nonsense. It's the government, expect the government. The work place is toxic AF
cons: Toxic environments, contract work, management, advancement, defeating

text: Salary is good compared with private places.Follows Code of Ethics, overviewed by Ministry of Health. Moderate Benefit plan. If a Person who is dedicated/ Caring  to serve the Elderly, best place to work in the Long- term care run by City Of Toronto.

People there's so selective jealous, rudes people that I never knew. You cannot work in paz there's always something that everyday changes, everybody thinks that their are the boss, people with seniority are the worse people in life, they feel like untouched because the union, etc.
Management is very rude, has little to no communication and training. Often mess up your hours and you do not get paid for months.
Good place to work. Good growth opportunity. Good Management that is willing to help growth. Provides good work-life balance. Good pay and benefits. Highly recommend.
Lots of opportunities for advancement   Pension and benefits are great. Good salary. Lots of flexibility to move around city if you want to be close to home

It's fun supervising and socializing the visitors while on duty. The only difficult time was to clear out the pool and making sure the pets don't get inside the pool otherwise it'll be contaminated and must be drained and refilled again. Other than that, the colleagues were also fun

Great place to work.  Lots of pools and community centres in the city - both indoor and outdoor. If you like working with kids and teaching swimming, you will enjoy this job.  Hours are flexible and the team atmosphere is nice.  On-going training opportunities are also available and opportunities for positions of increased responsibility.

As a student, I worked at City of Toronto as a Support Assistant and I have nothing, but wonderful things to say. I had a team that was highly supportive of me and a manager that was a blessing from God (you can't say this about many managers across any corporate environment). Day to day job looked like taking inbound calls and directing customers to the appropriate section, and also processing payments over the phone for those that have outstanding payments on the application. You've got an hour lunch too which is great!

It's a really productive workplace, and having access to numerous programmes has helped me develop my management skills significantly. Particularly when it comes to the various cultural teams, the management staff is quite helpful. Being aware of everything happening at once is the most difficult aspect.

It all depends on who your Manager is and the people on your team. I, unfortunately, have had to sacrifice a lot of my personal time to get where I am. All divisions are different, and I was not in one of the more supported divisions. Work culture can be draining because if you're not part of the 'boys club' and if you set appropriate boundaries, they can often diminish the level of respect you worked so hard to obtain.
Great place to get coaching experience. They ensure you are well trained and prepared to deal with all common situations. Supportive staff who help each other out when needed.
Clear job roles however long term colleagues own units and lord it over newcomers.Fault finding culture and tendency to demean others is a way of work.

Pretty easy job, you dont do much plus you make a lot of great friends. Work environment is very chill and relaxed. Easy money for the most part the way i see it. Would recommend to young people and students.

I’ve been working for the city since 16 as a high school student to when I was in university. It’s good as it offers seasonal positions that is flexible as a highschooler and even in university. However other than camps and program, there’s not much room for growth only if you want to become a location coordinator or area coordinator for a camp/program. Work culture among camp counsellors was great for me and outside of work, we were all pretty close. Management/ Facility Directors lacks diversity, although everyone under them is  diverse.
Since I worked with kids I had fun a lot of the time, we all kept each other busy. There is no real bad side to this job just some of the coworkers are rude.
great salary, competitive, great benefitsworked on callwork hours are based on seniorityhiring for permanent position is based on seniority levels too

I was a Waterfront Lifeguard at Woodbine Beach this past summer. Best job i've ever had. The people where amazing even with the little bits of drama. The salary is fantastic, increasing when I was there. The work-life  balance isn't great but the work becomes your life in all the best ways! Only complaint is the promotion system sucks as it depends on your city of Toronto hours as apposed to your Waterfront Lifeguard hours which can lead to some questionable promotion. All in all it was a great experience and I'll be returning next summer!
Great place to improve skills, good pace to make new connections, and learn new skills. If you like to teach kids how to learn new skills and have fun with sports, this is the place.

Working in the summer and earning on the side was worth both the experiences and my time. It allowed me to understand certain work ethics that allowed me to be the person that I am today. I recommend working for the City of Toronto as a summer camp leader/counselor only for the experience and not for your overall career longevity.

pros: Good pay + benefit programs, contribution toward community, relationship building opportunity with co-workers during the shift

text: Experience with the city has been great but it honestly depends on who you're working under. Higher-ups are very rude & hostile & have no interest in getting to know the people who work for them. The CRPs that I've had are great though.
Most teams are awesome. 7 hours workday. 1 hour mandatory lunch break. In hand salary is less due to most of contributions to omers. Teams are mostly collaborative.

Good place to work if they got rid of the politics. Some of the bosses like the lady one I had don’t care about all of their employees. They only care about whoever would take care of their personal interests which creates tension. Certain employees can go and come as they please but when others try,  they are disciplined

The City of Toronto offers very reasonable pay and has good benefits for part-time. The staff are very friendly and treat other staff well. The work environments are clean and each staff member is able to contribute to the space.
Municipal government work is demanding involving long hours where if you calculate yhe hours that you work versus your salary, i think its on par with McDonalds.
The supervisor always tried to humiliate & tried to prove that you don’t know anything & was not giving you any solution because he/she also doesn’t know
cons: Very bad staff, incompetent supervisor, manager. Will never work for the employer

text: It’s an excellent employer and provides staff good benefits working almost 13 years in long term care division give me more challenges and learning experience. Working with multi cultural diversity is an experience I have to be proud of 🙏🏻👍
Overall the best place I have ever worked. A lot of challenges dealing with children on a daily basis but avery rewarding experience. Most people are team players.

Productive, fast-paced, innovative, swift evolving workforce especially during COVID as things raoidly changed we had to change our way of providing care and promoting confort also.We work long hours as Long Term care is 24 hours and the demand for excellent care is high yet attainable.We do celebrate residents cultural diversity and other events

Working in the city of Toronto is a job for life,good place to Work nice people around.Different people and culture you meet with. thank Good Salary and Benefits The management are good. From nursing staff,FSW,Laundry,housekeeping keeps the home safe.

Usually understaffed so it was more physically demanding on me. The pay is alright for what I do but the hours could be longer.Decent job if it's your first job and you're looking for work experience!
Easy job, lots of people go here to have families and retire. Unfortunately that's not good for anyone looking to advance in their career or life. Don't do it if you aren't ready to give up.
Good position to get experience and opportunity to move into other positions depending on your interests or your background. Great staff to work with.

I am enjoying my job here at the city, for the first time In my career I can truly say I love my job! The managers are awesome, my colleagues are really great to work with, the pay, the benefits, the genuine love and respect for each other is amazing!

For a long term career this is an excellent place to work, there are many avenues for advancement and great benefits. There are a lot of policies to follow but this is the job, I have had experiences with some difficult management styles, but if this is your career path you will survive the reward.

If you love a fast paced environment and hard work with lots of overtime and great benefits this is the place for you. Work culture is pretty good but depends on nurse and floor you work on. Although stressful job at times a simple smile or thank you from one of your residents makes you want to continue to go over and beyond for all the residents. Also very accommodating and supportive if you're going back to school. Overall a great place to work.

I was terminated before I got into the union. I hurt my neck at work, and called my manager to tell him. My manager said that I never called him. I guess it's a good place for some people but it seemed like they were out to get me. I found it a poisonous atmosphere.
If you love kids and have good coworkers and a good supervisor, your swim instructor shift at work will be very enjoyable. Otherwise, I would opt to pick up Lifeguarding shifts only.

Over was a good place to work. Staff and CRPS worked as a team to ensure the sites were good. Working with the children was always something to look forward to. They would be excited to come to the after school program!

Definitely a chill work environment.Pay is good, but you only work 6 months of the year or so, and they have failed to raise wages in a way that reflects inflation.If you can handle working outdoors in the heat you'll enjoy it.Good hard work is not rewarded, the only thing that matters to the city is how many years you've been there.

text: You are able to work different sessions allowing you to be flexible with when you work. The Supervisors are helpful, and have a fast reponse time through email.

I worked as a waterfront lifeguard at the bluffs, it's one of the most intense beaches which would need one of the most supportive non drama and that was not the case, supervisors were immature, poor communication made the job dangerous, I ended up in the hospital due to intense training, bad communication  and anxiety. I just walked away and never came back.
pros: Nice thunder storm view at the bluffs, Will definitely face a lot of situations, You will get super fit
cons: As suggested by management, blow whistle incase you get kidnapped or stabbed or whatever

text: Good job lots room to grow and network you meet great people working with the city never hesitate to answer questions sometimes managers aren't easy to deal with but it's a very relaxed job for the most part
cons: Some managers aren't easy to please

text: Its hard work but you get to go home at a decent time every day and its 4 days a week. Had a lot of home time, felt like I was working a part time job and still got huge paychecks every pay. The supervisors dont bug you and leave you alone. No micro managing at all from my experience. The job is physically hard but its simple.
I worked there for a season and hope to return after covid politics are removed but it was a great job with good people. I learned a lot and look forward to my next season.

It's a good and secure job and being unionized can be a bonus. Unfortunately, top management changes fast which makes it hard to know who you are reporting to or be able to build a relationship with. Lack of communication can be an issue in regard to trainings and shifts.

It good to be sure that you are flexible with time. This city is a great place to work, it just takes a bit to get hired. They are a bit back tracked so if you don't hear back right away dont worry. The opportunity can still happen Goodluck.
Fantastic place to work they really care about the employees and great work culture. Good benefits and opportunities within the company. I would reccomend

Great place to work but favoritism is rampant. Management are all white and 80 percent of employees working directly with citizens are black or brown...Routinely mislead public and many people have no idea the hard work the majority of city staff do to offset higher ups repeated failures and this includes council as well.

Great for the employee but if you want to feel like you’re actually accomplishing something, this is not the place for you. Typical government.  Hires people not qualified just because they’re nice people lol
cons: Work on the same project for years without anything getting done

text: I love my co-workers! My time with the City was very memorable. I am very happy to have been a part of this team. Great work experience! Would recommend!!!

Overall a good place to work with excellent benefits and training opportunities. Different divisions have different culture. People are nicer and more relaxed in union heavy offices. Offices undergoing restructuring can be challenging to work in with high turnaround and constant changes - sometimes unorganized. Well established corporate policies.

My opinion on:-a typical day at work--fast paced, but fun.  Working with a team a team of like minded people.-what you learned--communication skills-management-- hierarchical -workplace culture-- fun and lively
Working at the city of Toronto is very good. A very good work life balance and usually supervisors are relaxed and gice you the days off requested. Good atmosphere.
pros: Flexible, A lot of time off

text: looks great on resumeslearned how to work in a big corporationworkplace culture can be very high schoolThe hardest part of the job is having to work with people from all walks of life. From your co workers to the community membersMost enjoyable part pf the job was meeting different types of people and learning new things from them.
Management was very supportive and colleagues were friendly and helpful as well. Good work culture. Lots of support to improve as a new employee. Many people stay at the organization.

Like most public sector jobs, great place to work if you want work-life balance, job security, and strong benefits. The downside is there is less opportunity for advancement and no opportunity to negotiate higher pay.
Great student jobmixture of watching pools and teaching kids how to swimcan be stressful and busy sometimesbut also can be relaxed and easyrewarding team atmosphere
pros: Great student job, outdoors, summer job, above minimum wage

text: Typical 8am-4pm working shift. Not a lot of overtime so great work and life balance. People are nice and helpful.  Management is great and easy to work with.

-Your enjoyment of the job is dependent on the location you are situated in. -Job is part time, good pay if you are a student in school even better pay if you pursue a coordiator position.-Leaders get paid additional money for short weekly meetings and program planning.-Only real difficult part is encouraging the children to play activities that are pre-planned.-tip to secure the job read and review program handbook, be familiar with concepts such as physical literacy and be aware of how to handle difficult situations with children for the job interview

text: In my short time there I was expects to hit the ground running, a lot of change occurred into the pandemic though. The people were amazing to work with and a great support. I would definitely choose to work there again, under normal circumstances though in an office setting with face to face time with colleagues and supervisors!
Made some great friends and was constantly encouraged by management. Very easy to maintain a work-life balance and opportunity to work as little or as much as you wanted.

Day to day tasks are often the same every day, your work is expected with the exception of being asked to complete random additional work that may come up.People are generally friendly and willing to help new staff learn. Management is good, usually relaxed unless your work isn’t completed.
pros: Friendly Staff, Available Overtime, Ability to transfer to practically any city department, Seasonal Recall
cons: Long Probationary Period, Takes a while to gain full time permanent status

text: Working for the. City of Toronto has greatly improve my nursing skills and given other other opportunities to sharpen my nursing. It’s a great place to work
pros: Excellent working environment and great management who are well equipped within their roles

text: once you have a city employee number you can do quite a lot within the city, most positions pay very well. Very based on seniority, room for growth is always there.
pros: Room for growth, part of union

text: Client focused work in a fast paced environment. Duties were constantly changing. Toughest part was any customer facing position, because there were times when situations required de-escalation. However, the processing side was more manageable.
pros: Great benefits, flexible schedule and fantastic managment.
cons: Almost impossible to move to other positions due to seniority.

text: Good place to advance your career and move laterally, diverse environment, job security and great pension plan. Many smart dedicated colleagues  and hardworking people
Super great work-life balance, ability to work around school schedules, awesome team environment. Would recommend for students or as a part time side job.

Okay, management was fine. They encourage people not to be open minded.No room for corrections. Also don't believe in you especially when you are new.You face difficulties when you came in new and ready to fight for stay.

This was a great job until the COVID crisis happened.  Employees were told that the vaccine wouldn't be mandatory, then 1 week later it was announced that vaccinations would be mandatory and not taking the vaccination would result in you being terminated.    And so, the City of Toronto has terminated employees who exercised their God given right to choose what they put in their bodies.  So, if you are content with working with an employer that feels it can tell you to put whatever in your body and fires you if you don't, knock yourselves out.

cons: No job security if you start on a contract

text: Had a great experience working for the city as a lifeguard, very relaxed environment and room for growth into supervisory roles. Great first job to start out

Relaxed atmosphere with an excellent work-place balance. No overtime are required. Strong team building and everyone is willing to help everyone out. Best workplace ever!

Great to work at City of Toronto.It gives a pleasure to work along with diverse background personalities. I recommend to try to work and serve the community. Your efforts are always appreciated, and acknowledged. You get an opportunity to learn policies which are reviewed and updated all the times. I feel proud to learn and go about each day.
pros: Best place to work. Gives you satisfaction, when you are able to accomplish your tasks every day

text: Pays well, lots of opportunities, generally good team. Usual office politics, exists but nothing out of the ordinary. If you are liked, more opportunities, if not, seek out your own opportunities. Opportunities exist.

text: Good part time job with management that understands you need to balance school and work. Pretty good pay for the work, work is not too difficult and a lot of great people.

It was impossible to move up in this job unless you were related to someone higher up.  The pay was excellent which is why I stayed for 9 years. There was much staff favoring both with higher up management (hiring very unqualified staff) as well as with scheduling  supervisors and staff.People were not treated fairly across the board.

Pros : pays well and with benefits even for part time employees Cons: no support from management Workload is too much unable to get your breaksFamilies abuse staff verbally and get away with it it’s like your walking on egg shells at work .

text: Environmental Projects , BIA Yorkville, opportunity, and range of projects were limitless, archives, and development works.  Exposure to a city that was growing.

Great place if you're happy with being small cog in large machine.  Can be frustrating if you really care about your work because they often have illogical processes. But if that's OK then reasonable pay, benefits, safe, and can be exciting at times.

never lose sight of the fact you are working for the municipal government and there is huge political component to every job. Its not whats right or wrong - its what the politically correct view and flavor of the day is.
cons: lazy entitled union employees. Well disguised nepotism

text: Working as a paramedic in Toronto means nothing to management or the City it's self.  Your just a number there and to advance in ANY kind of way means getting on your knees and giving the best possible BJ you can give.  Management there is so corrupt, so disgusting, so pathetic, that most medic's do the least possible work they can do.
cons: Long hours, horrible dispatching, pathetic management, dirty ambulances

text: Easily becoming one of the worst paramedic services in the province. Turn over rate is 3-5 years and dropping. The service has too many unsupportive and uneducated people in management. They care more about their egos than the patients and the general public. They have cut the advanced care paramedics in half and have reduced the number of stations that actually staff advanced care medics. They have done this without the general public having any clue. The service is now hiring new paramedics and putting them on the road even though they have failed their orientation and preceptorships. Management and education know they are unfit and actually dangerous to the general public but still, put them out there because they need the bodies. Scary times to be in this service or city. Caution
pros: Gain a lot of experience in a short time

text: If you are the type of person who actually enjoys getting work done and completing projects or working in an organized fashion, this is place is not for you. The City of Toronto, most of its divisions, is very disorganized. Simple decisions are forced into complex and convoluted meetings where even the most irrelevant staff are granted an opinion.  Meetings across nearly all divisions generally contain way too many staff and there is way too much opinion and feeling validation rather than objective organization and decision making.  It is said that having so many people accountable and responsible for tasks effectively leaves no one responsible, this is the City of Toronto.A good example of the ineffectiveness and poor planning of leadership was my own technical unit, which had only 2 labouring staff and 3 supervisors and 2 managers.  After complaining that I wasn't given any work for 6 months (I provided documentation for this) it took 3 supervisors and 1 manager to come together and they didn't have work for me, they just asked me what I wanted to do.  Please note, that I was a white-collar office worker, a programmer and analyst.TO SAY THE CITY OF TORONTO IS DISORGANIZED IS AN UNDERSTATEMENTThat said, if you want a cushy job with great benefits a good pension and effectively zero responsibility, this is the place for you.  If you have zero expectations and don't care much if tax-payers money is being wasted, the City of Toronto as an employer is perfect for you.

A diverse working environment with opportunities to engage in independent strategic planning aligned City of Toronto Council identified priorities.Facilitating of community engagement and priority setting objectives
cons: Exteremely long work hours and obligations in developing communities of common bond

text: I am a current Solid Waste Collection Operator.4 day work weeks are a total bonus here! You have freedom here, no one is breathing down your neck. You work by yourself which I love! The benefits here are amongst the best possible, massages, dental, glasses, you name it, you are covered. Management is amazing with great folks. They want you to succeed here, unlike many other workplaces. Room for growth. Vacation & sick days are absolutely amazing! I have zero complaints about City Of Toronto. I will retire here :)
pros: Freedom, Benefits, Room for growth, 4 day work weeks

text: Constantly asked to work over time and doubles. Received calls in the middle of the night asking for you to come into work. Rude staff and supervisors.
Most of the employees want to work but the culture is hurry up and wait and things are not explained properly.  Management tends to micro manage employees.
Good and fast paced. Be ready to learn and help those in need.  As a CSW your role is vital to the well being of clients. The shutbkeader and othe CSW are very supportive

Some divisions have a good work / life balance, others promise it but don’t deliver. Some senior management aren’t open to new ideas and would rather do what they’ve always done than look at new options. You’re golden and untouchable when you / if you last 15 years up until anything goes.

Also to many senior workers who don't care and don't pull there wait and just constantly complain about nothing need to have a reality check. The union should really take a hard look at there practices on how they deal with people like this. I believe that some jobs will be lost because of there entitled behaviors.

text: The 2nd floor of City Hall is a terrible place to work.  City Councillors are accountable to nobody for how they treat/mistreat their staff and are free to demand anything they want.

It’s the best place to be a gardener in Toronto other than if you are running a landscaping company or work at a botanical garden or zoo. The pay and benefits are better then private sector, very generous benefits esp. almost zero stress for a gardener. Only thing is gardeners come from all different backgrounds and types, can be quirky big personalities, the conflicts I’ve seen are when the team leader is not actively managing well, people with dysfunctional behaviours stay at the job due to union protection, and lazy workers mixed with hard working ones.  Other than those (every job has its downsides) it is a place to work where you can learn a lot, do cool things you cannot do in most places on the scale the city can, and move to different yards each year and meet a lot of people.

text: It is a good place to work and get experience as a new grad. It is hard to advance due to seniority, I applied with graduate level just to get in with possibility of transferring to my field, it’s an illusion. It takes years to advance and your qualifications aren’t recognized it’s all about seniority. It’s best to do as a part time gig and have another job in which you are practicing your profession. The environment can be toxic at times, most people are in the job for money and not to serve the needs of the clients. Also, technology is very old and they use mainly paper. Lots of shift work nights evenings and mornings and you get schedule anytime so hardly no life balance.
cons: Toxic work environment, no recognition for qualifications/skills

text: I love my work. The City of Toronto is one of the best employers; great leadership and opportunity.... not to mention a strong union. I have the ability to work from home.  I am very grateful for that. Our workers changed a lot with the pandemic but I am so grateful for this job.

If you just want to work and you don't have a family member or a BFF or something similar don't waste your time.  It won't work like that. You will be only a ladder for those people.  Managers are gods with low , less education and you will be someone who should pray them everyday for letting you work there as they wish. No job security at all. You will be first step of the ladder and everyone use you and treat you like that. No future for regular person. In contrary if you have your buddy there, they don't care about your knowledge and experience,  you are hired. And lots of politics involved as well. So be prepared for such environment.

text: Easy to learn, get jobs done and no issues. Always have work to do. Supervisors are great! I really enjoy my job and working here. Drive sidewalk vac and pickup trucks.....
I love to work for the city I enjoy going to work every day great place to grow great management and people💯Friendly fun place to work and learn as you go

The city of Toronto is a very inclusive organization who promotes diversity and multiculturalism in the workplace. The City provides a broad variety of public services across the GTA. All employees are given annual training and are further training/ development programs are available. Jobs are secure and benefits are decent. Internal positions are available, however recruitment is seniority based which makes consideration and advancement quite difficult for newer employees (0-10 years experience).

text: I have worked for the city for 30 years.The pay and benefits are good.Job protection from the union.Very hard to get full-time it's mostly contract and part-time work.Really good job for someone who wants to just make extra money.Work with alot of different people
pros: Good pay, job protection, good benefits
cons: Workplace can be very stressful, bullying from staff and some management.

text: many jobs within find your path it will take care of you thats the city it is great many opportunitys managment is easy to work with very understanding and great benefits

My hourly rate increases by 27cents per year due to the contract. They cut back on health benefits, dental, foot etc. Work is somewhat stressful. Only good thing are vacation day,s about 35. Sick days about 20. Emergency days about 10. Also you can work for lot's of overtime - if it's approved and it's either paid overtime or lieu time.  When you pass a working benchmark (so if you work there for 10yrs, 15yrs 20yrs) they add one more week of paid vk for the year so thats good Overall 3/5 starts

Before I started working there, I kept on hearing how great of an employer the City is and that it is one of the best employers, but working there, I have to disagree. The salary is great, but definitely unrepresentative of the work you do. Management constantly adds more tasks and workload that is out your job description because there is a serious lack of staff. The mentality there is do more with less. Benefits are not as great as they are made out to be; first time that I ever had to pay anything at the dentist after having work done and a lot of major things are not covered or require doctor referrals. There's a lack of flexibility when it comes to working. Although colleagues are nice and understanding, different departments don't work together creating issues for service delivery. Very little room for advancement; they prefer hiring externally than promoting from within, and very often, new supervisors come in lacking the experience and insight to make appropriate decisions or understand the needs of your position. Most people on contract for years and still not permanent.
cons: Overworking, constant adding to job tasks, lack of flexibility, little room for advancement

Training and courses for career advancement were always available and encouraged. As with any workplace, there are always those who don't realize what they have, but there are many people who strive to do more, to do better and to learn new skills on the job.  I have had the privilege of working with people who had amazing ideas, and great skills and we completed tasks and projects I never imagined I would ever be doing in my career. I worked as a Team Leader for Diversion Program Assistant (DPA) with the City of Toronto. I was responsible for training of new hires, organize and plan daily work schedule to meet deadlines according to the routes, maps and multi-residential audits for identifying contamination in the recycling waste. I was able to establish, update and revise waste management service levels by interacting with Supervisors, external and internal staff on a day to day basis regarding the progress of the audits. I currently possess a valid G-permit for the City of Toronto. As a DPA, I was able to take initiatives and implement new strategies for the projects by analyzing information gathered through research, public consultation and pilot programs.  I have been part of commercial audits for verifying and gathering new City of Toronto customers for Solid Waste Division, Front End contamination audits for recycling, TCHC audits for safe recycling and garbage collection under the guidelines from Toronto fire, and York University curb side audits. My past work experience and current position has given me great interpersonal skills and communication skills including conflict resolution, problem solving, decision making and situational assessment. I adopt well to working beyond normal work days as requested, under varying climate conditions. I can work with minimum supervision and plan and execute tasks with the ability to set priorities.

Eight years of stakeholder management on a business transformation initiative has made me adept at managing expectations, understanding business models and eliciting business requirements to support those models. As the Enterprise Performance Management (EPM) Lead, on a City-wide IT SAP Implementation project, I was responsible for a variety of overlapping initiatives surrounding the development and utilization of performance measures. I successfully introduced a performance measurement framework into the organization’s annual budget cycle; effectively standardized and matured the manner in which key performance measures (KPI) were identified, documented, and reported. As the subject matter expert (SME) managing the project I created the work breakdown structure (WBS) to manage deliverables, gathered the requirements to build and test the solution, and maintained communications with 35 stakeholders. My colleagues acknowledge my ability to connect with various stakeholders while successfully managing the various aspects of the project; both agile and waterfall environments.

text: Working as a skating / hockey instructor was fantastic work. I am an avid hockey player and this was a close as I got to playing professionally (getting paid to play / teach hockey and skating). The hours were easy (often 2 / 3 hours a day) and the pay was good. I worked with another city employee to design and implement skating / hockey skill lessons. It was easy due to a background in both hockey and skating and was fun for me.  The hardest part of the job was parents trying to help their children interfering with my teaching. While this was not common, when it happened, it was often impossible for the children to block out their parents and listen to my instruction. The most enjoyable aspect of this job was when students would reach the point of being able to stand on their skates or to complete hockey drills they previously thought they would be unable to do.
pros: Getting paid to skate / play / teach hockey.

text: Answered inquiries from members and the public regarding programs and events .  Explained cost and completed transactions for new or returning members.  Input information into database regarding the number of members who attended specific classes. Enjoyable atmosphere, both staff and public were pleasurable to work with.  Very little stress other than when timelines were tight. I learned a variety of customer service skills such as communication,, problem solving, decision making and resolution skills.  I became knowledgable about the many programs offered at the City of Toronto Parks and Recreation Division.

My typical day at work used to start with good morning greetings, and then we were good to go and perform our daily tasks. I was able to learn coordination, management and technical skills from the City. Management staff were great and supportive.

The people you work with and meet at this job are kinda and helpful and you learn good people skills, how to deal with people. The salary and actually super good, I got around $16 an hour and for rink guard around $14- $15 an hour.

City of Toronto Ribfest was a very good experience while you’re working you are also learning on new things they tell you what to do . They’re an excellent company , the manager takes care of you by buying you pizza and drinks on the break and over time and they’re nice people .

text: You must be punctual and ready to work.  No slacking on the job.  Many guidelines to follow, policies, rules, and regulations.  Always make sure to go over the guidelines every month because they can changed in a second.

it was a very new and exciting way to come into the work atmosphere. it was very inviting, co-workers were kind and friendly. everyone cared about their job and tried to make each day a fun experience for everyone.

On a typical day my duty is to work on the telephone dealing with customers who want to use the City facilities and to register in program in which the City offers. Also, to help the customers to enroll their children into activities that will help them in their learning. Having to deal with customers helps me to understand the needs of the parents in having interest in their children's learning development.By communicatiing with parents increases my learning experience in the  area of recreation. In dealing with customers my management skills have improved. I also know how to multitask and address my customers' concerns on the phone by giving them instructions on how to use the computer to register for the different programs. The workplace culture involves a manager, supervisors, and staff, It contains a multicultural environment. The hardest part of the job is to help first time users to find the right programs. Also to deal with customers who are inclined to have a behavioral problem. The most enjoyable part of the job is to meet the needs of my customers. Also, to be able to develop good time management skills.
pros: To work in a multicultural setting

ProsWorking at the city was my first real office job and entry into a corporate environment. Working in the IT department was very relaxed. There's a fairly progressive vibe, you'll see people walk around to consult with other team members. Most of the full-time staff here are middle-aged (and older) adults who've been working here for decades, so the atmosphere is more like a toned-down, conservative, classic office. That's not to say they couldn't or didn't adapt to modern web technology though, which they were constantly looking at to implement. ConsAs a student, there wasn't much orientation and I didn't know what to expect in terms of company culture. My entry felt sort of impromptu. I also didn't learn much "on the job", but I guess that might've been expected with my novice qualifications and probably them not wanting to bring me onto a team that dealt with something important. I did pretty basic html (bootstrap) and javascript pages, as well as some minor QA, cleanup, and documentation. I appreciated the exposure though.

The City of Toronto has a lot of potential to be a great employer, but top level management is so poor that nothing gets done and changes take years to implement. Their web systems are behind the times and the IT department is hesitant to make changes because of the lengthy paperwork and approval process involved. Consequently, employees are left justifying old methodology and outdated systems to the public. Also, many positions are granted not to the best candidate but to a candidate with more seniority.

Working with the City of Toronto is great! You are able to do something you love and can use that as a form of exercise. Sometimes it gets very cold but that's okay, simple solution is to go inside, make a quick tea and warm up.  Usually I would get there about 5-10 minutes earlier then I would put all my proper equipment on which includes; CSA approved helmet, skates, whistle, fanny pack full of first aid products and luminescent vest. At first I was nervous because I was young and not confident but then I gained confidence and learned that I was great with talking to people and great with helping them in anyway possible. Unfortunately, in the past year (almost 2) my managers have changed but they were both very nice people to work with. The co-workers are great because everyone is around the same age. Some new young workers come so I get to share my knowledge and experience with them and answer an questions they have and make sure they don't get as nervous as me when I first started.
pros: Get to do what you love and skating is a form of exercise!
cons: Sometimes gets too cold to stay outside for long hours

Assisting seniors and persons with disabilities to continue living in their homes is priority.  My office offers federal/provincial funding for lower-income seniors and persons with disabilities who wish to make health and safety repairs to their homes. Answer phone calls/emails/front desk inquiries. Process paperwork for funding approval and issuing of funding.. Maintain data base on funding and provide reports to theCity of Toronto and  Ministry. I work with four Program Officers and assist them with the applications at different stages of the funding process. Hardest part of my job is letting people know they are NOT eligible for our programs because of income, repair/modification item or their property value is too high. Helping a senior/person with disability live in their own homes independently.      .

text: It was a day that every citizen in Toronto needed to voted on which mayor they chose. I, on the other hand had various duties. There was many multicultural people that did not understand what the MDRO was explaining to them. Therefore, I spoke French and Italian to them to explain what they have to do . The MDRO appreciated my well communication skills and it was helpful that I know three languages. I also helped the hard of hearing people, I learned how to do sign language because I took an after school club learning the alphabet in sign language and on that day it absolutely helped me through the say. When it got very bus around 6pm I held the door open for the people to come in and explained to them to be prepared when they need to vote. When it was closing time I helped clean up kept everything organized I helped count the votes brought down the signs, and locked the doors so nobody came in. There were some people that were complaining but I kept them calm and helped them out and they thanked me at the end when they finished voting.
cons: No free lunch or free time was always busy.

text: I love human resources and, in particular, labour relations.  Therefore, the City was a great place to rise to never ending challenges.  This was especially true during amalgamation.   The work atmosphere changes quite often as senior management often have conflicting human resources philosophies from their predecessors and that sometimes required a 180 degree change in thinking on the part of managers.  The hardest part of the job was the enormous amounts of time that I was away from my family.  Sometimes living in downtown hotels for months at a time.  The most enjoyable part of the job was knowing that we were helping and making a difference for the residents of Toronto, management and operations as well as making the City as good a work place for line staff as possible.
pros: Generous benefit package and pension plan

text: I work split shift and I am in the room with the Registered Early Childcare Educator, assisting with daily duties such as diaper changing, feeding, ect. I learned to be very patient when dealing with staff, parents, and children. I understood the value of maintaining personal and private information of parents and children. The staff at most sites have been great to work with and have taught me a lot. Some, life lessons, and others, on-the-job skills. The hardest part of the job would be to prioritize the workload. There is so much to get done in any given day that you have to delegate what is top priority and working down to what can be saved for last. The most enjoyable part of the job is to be able to have a great report with staff and bonding with the children.
Absolutely most stressful job on the earth. Low pay and bad management result in a stressful work environment. Good co-workers, they're all dieing with you at work so it's a team thing.
great work environment election work. lifting, assembly work.

There was nothing more rewarding than watching my students perform during their annual recital and hearing all the positive feedback from their parents. This job taught me valuable skills in program management, organization, customer relations and communication.

text: A typical day at work was rather simple while working as a rink guard. I would come into work make sure the workplace was clean and respectable. Than, I would put on my safety equipment  and get on the ice. Once I was on the ice I would do my rounds ensuring that everyone had the proper equipment on and that they were following city of Toronto mandated instructions. During this job I learned several things, I learned the importance of creative problem solving (while dealing with disgruntled customers ), as well as the importance of being energetic and warm in an effort to promote a safe environment for patrons. One of the best part of the jobs were my co-workers, I got along with every single one of my co-workers including any management I worked with. I was specifically pleased with the management as I had heard so many horror stories and was expecting the worse but in reality I got a very reasonable staff of managers. The hardest part of the job was dealing with patrons who were not happy, some times I felt as if customers had valid arguments but, according to the city of Toronto they were wrong. Thus, I had to side with the City as that was my job and that's what I signed up for. The most enjoyable part of my job was constantly being outside and interacting with the lovely people of my community.
pros: Good Coworkers, Good Management, Good benefits.

text: Good place to work, very enthusiastic co-workers, learned a lot working at this place. A place to give respect, dignity and care to residents. Management gives no respect to its employees, treats them as garbage, no open door policy, a sense of racism still exists.

This job allows for me to learn about diverse backgrounds in a non-judgmental and professional manner.

text: only lasted for a summer     its mainly for kids in high school to save money for college

I check my truck  and do my circle check, after that I start on my map, we switch with my partner at least half an hour each time, our supervisor is good he trust we can finish the map so he doesnt bother us. The hard part is when sometimes furniture is wet and is really heavy so both of us have to lift at the same time and sometimes that takes alot of time from work. The most enjoyable part of my job is not only do I only work 4 days but if you push yourself in the day, you finish quicker and that means get home sooner.
it would start with a circle check of truck , arguing with supervisors in regards to what area to work in , help others in there areas when I was finished my area ,

Every day was different and interesting. Working under the Rob Ford administration provided many insights into the whole process of municipal priority and budget setting.  The City has a very rigorous budget process and managed to reduce most departmental budgets by 10%.

-Provided information about community services and resources available for youth -Developed and implemented a variety of recreational programs and camps for youth e.g. basketball, soccer, and floor hockey -Supervised and positively interacted with children -Oversee the homework program and provide individual tutoring -Prepared complete and accurate daily records and report

program itself is good, could be great if management knew how to promote, do needs assessments, extend the program length, treat all their employers with respect and give positive feedback to everyone instead of making employees feel like they have nothing else going for them   my summer camp supervisors are great, and program runs better with longer hours and proper supervision, and everyone is on the same page and supervisors are respectful
Great Staff and really enjoyed my time here.  Perfect Type of employment to balance with school.
Good workplace for ongoing development of horticultural skills.

A typical day at work as a wading pool attendant was fun but extremely tiring. I had to be up before everyone to make sure that the pool was open for the kids for them to swim. The summer I did work for the city of Toronto, it was extremely hot. But the children made it all worth it, we played games in the water such as basketball, tag, marco polo. The parents really appreciated the fact that I showed interest in playing with their children and making sure that they had themselves a good time. Working for the city of Toronto, i learned how to open pools, I also learned a lot of rules about the pool that I never knew before. My Co-workers and supervisor were really nice, we used to plan games together and then ask the kids which games they wanted to play. The hardest part about the job was being out in the sun everyday with no shade for more than 5 hours. The most enjoyable part about the job was just being able to put a smile on some of these kids' faces, especially the kids that were the only children in their families that only came with their parents. We definitely made sure they had fun.
Everyone was so kind at the Municipal Licensing and Standards Division while I was with them.
Nice working environment. Learn new things every other day. Typical local government style management. Unions

I'm working as a Client Service Worker at a City-operated shelter. Work environment is challenging but it is a rewarding job if you have empathy and tolerance. Pay is good, but you should be available for shift work including overtime shift.
pros: Good pay + benefit programs, contribution toward community, relationship building opportunity with co-workers during the shift
cons: Challenging work environment including the facility and people

text: I really enjoyed my time working for the City of Toronto. I worked with some really good people who always motivated me.
pros: Working with great people, working with children, implementing health and wellness activities the way I would like to
cons: A lot of trainings and meetings.

text: Through my years of working at the City of Toronto I would say it was a great experience.  You learn a lot quickly and it is very cultured.  I didn't stick to one 'title' but was moved around a lot and macro-managed a lot of different projects, which I loved.  The environment was great and so were the hours.

I was able to not only better the lives of patrons through teaching them a life saving skill, but my position allowed me to better their life emotionally as well, even if only for the time they spent with me. The compliments and reviews I received made me know that I was leaving a lasting and positive effect on all patrons I came in contact with.
cons: People can take advantage of the Job security.

text: A typical day at work is assessing residents with responsive behaviour. I have to model and suggest techniques for staff members. I do overviews and documentations for each client. I've learned and implented a variety of methods on how to handle clients with different types of behaviours. I work hand in hand with my management team. The most enjoyable part of my job is being able to enhance the quality of life for my clients.

Help small business owners distinguish different business structures and research information for them as requestedHelp set up booth and be there to provide answers in trade showsThis job helps one to develop communication and client service skills, it also requires leadership skills because one has to make the call when helping clientsThe co-workers are friendly and willing to helpThe most enjoyable part of the job is to help client develop their career

Providing access to information and Citizenship for residents of the City of Toronto. Very interesting work doing research, advocacy for the public.  Enjoyed both  written and individual communication with both the public and elected officials.
After working there for 9 years I have encountered good staff and excellent managers. Working for the City of Toronto is something I would recommend to anyone.
Loved working with the City of Toronto, extremely inclusive and helpful to all of its staff.

I am responsible for researching, writing, analyzing and editing documents issued by the Mayor, Members of Council and Divisions.  I produce politically and culturally sensitive documents of a diverse nature with clarity and precision while maintaining several databases and reports daily. This position has allowed me to utilize my written, analytical, communicative and interpersonal skills to the highest degree while working in a highly confidential setting

Love to be extremely Busy , and I enjoy the people I work with and my team is very passionate and hard working and makes my day go faster and easy , even though its high stress job with lot of risk factors and dealing with lot of people with minds and thoughts , but just staying calm and focussed makes it stress free day .

A typical day at work consisted of interacting with many patrons and assuring their safety at the pool. I have learned to communicate effectively with different types of people as we get a lot of people coming into the pool each and everyday. I also learned to work well with little kids as I had to teach them. The management was great as I was never confused as to who I reported to. I enjoy spending time with my co-workers as we were all similar in age (students) and we would have a lot to talk about during break times. The hardest part of the job is when a patron gives you a hard time because you have to always keep your calm even when you know they are wrong.
pros: great pay for a student (above minimum wage)

text: Taught piano, kids were fine, a lot of lazy coworkers, everyone doing it for the money or as a stepping stone to something else they'd like to do.
Its a nice place to work on. I want to move on and get an 8 hour full time Job with Benefits

Working for the municipality of the mega city presents a large opportunity to discover different avenues in which one can prosper. Toronto offers the most variety of programs to suit anyone's needs. Being a part of such a large group of dedicated workers felt great.
Working for the city of toronto is great because it is well respected.the most enjoyable part of the job is seeing the progress and smiles of each student.
Would provide children with a 2 week program to educate them further in dance, We would provide trips, and shows at the end of the year. This required managing a schedule, and budget planning.

I worked in focus on youth which is a summer job . i learnt how to be a team player and how to take care of kids . I knew my co-works so i had fun with them . The  hardest part of the job the is some of the kids dont really listen to us .
A typical day consists of maintaining a safe environment for patrons and ensuring the safety of children.
I developed skills in policy paper research, briefing notes and working in a fast paced municipal government workspace.

i learned to work hard and you will be rewarded. Some of the management didn't allow you to instill your vision and lack understanding of what direction to go in. the clients were great and it was an honor to serve them.

A typical day at work entailed greeting all visitors and directing them to various personnelReceiving and screening telephone calls and transferring to the right department as well as taking messages and relaying to the relevant staff memberEnjoyed working as part of a team to organize internal fundraising eventsEffectively performed general administrative functions

text: Face to face customer service each day dealing with public and clients alike.Meeting weekly deadlines and continuously under pressure with two week cycle. cons: work isn't as fulfilling as i would like.

text: I love to keep learning and work with high performance teams in order to provide the best bilingual customer service. Last years typical day was working two jobs. First starting at 6 a.m. landscaping. This would require a lot of digging, moving dirt and planting/replanting. After this i would go to my second job, lifeguarding. This would consist of dealing with patrons problems, ensuring all around safety for everyone and ensuring rules are followed. There doesn't have to always be a hard day, but the heat can sometimes be difficult with lack of water. The most enjoyable would be the cool swim at the end.
Working with city as support c. Learn about inventory, supply, materials order according requirment.

I enjoy working for the City of Toronto. They are able to provide me with working hours that are suitable for my schedule. Strong accommodation from my employer, highly PR oriented staff and approachable team.

Typical day you welcome parents and children in the early morning begining at 7:00am. Care for children teaching life skills throughout the day as required. Management is very strict with ground rules. However, they can be fun and outgoing. Your co-workers are fun to work with. They have the ability to work under stress with a smile on their faces despite having a difficult day. The hardest part is saying goodbye to children who are graduating to another level or leaving the centre permanently. Also seeing a child taken away by child protective services. The most enjoyable part is seeing the children grow up right before your eyes from infants to teenagers, and sometimes young adults returning with their own bundle of joy for you to care for them.
pros: room to learn and grow in the filed.
cons: can be very frustrating enviroment. expectations are very high.

text: It is a diverse work environment where employees are treated with dignity and respect. A typical day at work can be unpredictable you are never able to premeditate what might take place. Management is great , always there for support. Co-workers are team players always working together. The most enjoyable part of this job is rewarding feeling at the end of the day , knowing you are a positive influence in the children's lives.

Many varying opportunities to grow and develop different financial as well as non-financial skills.Many opportunities to develop leadership skills such as understanding and developing communication nuances of staff with multicultural backgrounds.
pros: opportunities to appreciate the formal internal control structures of a large organization
cons: formalities has inherent restrictions and bureaucracy which slows the pace of achievements

text: Reports to the Labour Relations Manager and contributes to the goals and objectives of the City of Toronto• Assists the Labour Relations Consultants with ongoing administrative including supporting with the gathering of information to prepare grievance files, arbitration cases for appropriate proceedings and the interpretation of CUPE Local 416 and 79 Collective Agreements• Prepares statistical reports using the Grievance Tracking System (GTS) of types and frequency of actions taken concerning grievances, arbitration, mediation, and related labour relations activities to identify problem areas• Researches and conducts relevant data to support City of Toronto’s Progress Report on Equity, Diversity and Human Rights (EDHR) Achievements
pros: great labour relations department with supportive mentors

text: I work part time as a fitness instructor with people from different cultures and age groups. I can strongly say, I have good communication/people skills, as well as patience and dedication. I enjoy helping people reach their fitness goals and will help them as much as I possibly can in order for them to be satisfied.
pros: meeting different people, getting to work with them closely
cons: wish to have more hours, looking for a more stable, full time job

text: A typical day involves working with the general public, staff, contract workers and politicians on various projects and activities. The hardest part of the job is dealing with union grievances and scheduling due to continued budget cut backs and reduced budgets.The most enjoyable part of the job is working with capital project staff, community organizations and members of the public to keep them healthy and active with what ever activities they are involved with.In addition, assisting the various community cultural organizations and associations in acquiring space and/or information on accessing city services and facilities.
pros: the various number of people you meet and have the opportunity to work with.
cons: not enough hours in a day to help those who need it.

text: Typical day at work included heading out to construction site - ensure contractor's work is up to specifications, take measurements and write cost sheets for payment.Management and co-workers were very helpful in teaching me the ropes of this profession and helping me learn what to look for in various construction activities and how to ensure work is according to City of Toronto specifications.Hardest part of job was to make on-site decisions which would often require work costing more than what was planned for.
pros: great work atmosphere and ability to work independently.

text: I enjoy the City of Toronto because the day allows for a variety. I have learned that putting customers first (in this case families first) is absolutely essential to ensuring they have what they need.The management team is always there to help and answer any questions and provide other opportunities for growth.My co-workers are friendly and are team players so that makes it easy to get along.The hardest part is dealing with residents who have such severe dementia for instance they're unable to effectively stay what they desire and I'm unfortunately unable to help like I wish.The most enjoyable is making the residents who wish to share their life story, smile and feel loved.

text: As Information and Technology Supervisor, my duties included developing applications for different Departments.I was also the Microsoft Server Administrator and was in charge of writing a monthly summary of Microsoft and Oracle licenses used by the Departments for the IT Director and Manager.

In my opinion the City of Toronto is the best place to work. The workplace are a friendly environment that you never feel tired.

text: The City of Toronto is expanding with residents arriving from all over the World. The City needs to gear to these changes. At this time, the City is a hard place to work as economic times are bad.Pleasant place if career goal to work as a municipal employee.

I really enjoy the environment and people i am working with. It is a fun and exciting job to come to.
Relaxed Enviornment - Slow Pace work. City is great place for some one looking for work life balance and great job security.

This employer has good pay and has excellent benefits!They are flexible and understanding on personal needs for time off.However, morale seems to be a bit low due to the fact the City is over accommodating to certain indentified employees then others.
